qas.question: What is the term for the player that is currently handing the football when play is underway?
Within what distance from the line of scrimmage can offensive players who do not have the ball be legally contacted by defensive players?
What are two illegal ways to block an opposing player's progress near the line of scrimmage?
Which player may not be tackled immediately after they have thrown a pass?
What player can be legally tackeled when tripping the player he intends to block?
What player can't be interfered with unless he is within one yard of any player?
Which player may not be contacted after the kick after throwing a pass?
What are two illegal ways to currently be in possession of the ball near the line of scrimmage?
When is the rule applied where the offensive player may not be contacted?

context: There are many rules to contact in this type of football. First, the only player on the field who may be legally tackled is the player currently in possession of the football (<b4_0>the <a0_0>ball carrier<b4_0/><a0_0/>). Second, a receiver, that is to say, <b5_0>an offensive player<b5_0/> sent down the field to receive a pass, may not be interfered with (have his motion impeded, be blocked, etc.) unless he is within <a1_0>one yard<a1_0/> of the line of scrimmage (instead of 5 yards (4.6 m) in American football). Any player may block another player's passage, so long as he does not <a2_0><b7_0>hold or trip<b7_0/><a2_0/> the player he intends to block. The kicker may not be contacted <b8_0>after the kick<b8_0/> but before his kicking leg returns to the ground (this rule is not enforced upon a player who has blocked a kick), and the <a3_0><b6_0>quarterback<b6_0/><a3_0/>, having already thrown the ball, may not be hit or tackled.
